facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 10, 1953, of the Calcutta High Court  Original Side  in I. T. Reference No. 8 of 1947.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 10, 1953 of Calcutta High Court Original Side in I.T. Reference No. 8 of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 10, 1953, of the Calcutta High Court  Original Side  in I. T. Reference No. 8 of 1947. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General for India, G. N. Joshi and B. H. Dhebar, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Supreme Court on April 24, 1957 by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. April 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-This appeal raises a question of importance as to whether amounts shown by an insurance companypany as reserves for unexpired risks on pending policies are liable to be deducted under r. 2 of Sch. II to the Excess Profits Tax Act  XV of 1940  hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Respondent is a company carrying on life, fire, marine and general insurance business.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a companypany carrying on life, fire, marine and general insurance business, and the present dispute relates to the assessment of excess profits tax on its income from business other than life insurance for the chargeable accounting periods ending December 31, 1940, and December 31, 1941.

facts.text: Dispute relates to excess profits tax assessment on income from business other than life insurance for periods ending December 31, 1940 and December 31, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a companypany carrying on life, fire, marine and general insurance business, and the present dispute relates to the assessment of excess profits tax on its income from business other than life insurance for the chargeable accounting periods ending December 31, 1940, and December 31, 1941.

facts.text: Insurance policies concerned are issued for short periods or ad hoc for specified voyage or event, e.g., fire policies normally for one year with full premium received upfront.

anchor.surface_text: To appreciate the companytentions raised, it is necessary to state that the policies of insurance with which these proceedings are companycerned, are, unlike life insurance policies, issued in general for short periods or ad hoc in relation to a specified voyage or event. To take the most important of them, fire insurance policies, they are issued numbermally for one year, and the whole of the premium due thereon is received when the policies are actually issued.

facts.text: Respondent's accounting method: premiums received fully included in assets, 40% treated as reserve for unexpired risks shown as liability.

anchor.surface_text: The method 1004 adopted by the respondent in preparing the above statements has been that while the premiums received are all of them included in the assets of the year, a certain proportion thereof, usually 40 per cent., is treated as the reserve for unexpired risks, and that is shown as a liability.

facts.text: Example: In 1939, respondent issued fire policies receiving Rs. 1,00,000 premiums; full amount shown as income/assets, Rs. 40,000 as reserve for unexpired risks as liability.

anchor.surface_text: To take a companycrete example, if in the year 1939 the respondent issued annual fire insurance policies and received a sum of Rs. 1,00,000 as premiums thereof, the whole of it would be shown as income in the statement for the year 1939, and a sum of Rs. 40,000 will be shown as a reserve for unexpired risks.

facts.text: This accounting method is usually adopted by insurance companies and in accordance with approved accountancy practice.

anchor.surface_text: This method of account- keeping is what is usually adopted by insurance companypanies, and is in accordance with well-recognised and approved practice of accountancy.

facts.text: Question: Whether Rs. 40,000 reserve set apart in 1939 is deductible under r.2 Sch.II EPT Act from capital employed including full Rs.1,00,000 premiums.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the question is whether in the illustration given above, the sum of Rs. 40,000 which is set apart in 1939 as reserve for unexpired risks is liable to be deducted under r. 2 of Sch. II to the Act from out of the capital employed in business for that year, which would, of companyrse, include the whole of Rs. 1,00,000 received as premiums.

facts.text: Appellant contends reserves represent outstanding liability for unexpired period and deductible as liability under r.2 Sch.II.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellant is that if all the premiums received are to be treated as capital under r. 1, Sch. 11, then the sums which represent the outstanding liability in respect of the unexpired period of the policies-in the illustration given above, Rs. 40,000-should be deducted as a liability under r. 2 of Sch. II.

facts.text: Respondent claims premiums as capital but provision for unexpired risks is contingent liability not within r.2 Sch.II.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, while claiming that all the premiums received mu-,it be treated as capital, maintains that the provision for unexpired risks is- a companytingent liability, and that that 1005 is number within r. 2 of Sch. II.

The Tribunal decided the question against the respondent, but on reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act read with s. 21 of the Act, the High Court of Calcutta answered the question adversely to the appellant, but granted a certificate under s. 66-A, and that is how the appeal companyes before us.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court on reference under s.66(1) IT Act r/w s.21 EPT Act answered against appellant and granted certificate under s.66A.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal decided the question against the respondent, but on reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act read with s. 21 of the Act, the High Court of Calcutta answered the question adversely to the appellant, but granted a certificate under s. 66-A, and that is how the appeal companyes before us.

facts.text: Reserve of 40% of premiums shown in statements furnished to Controller of Insurance under Insurance Act 1938, treated as liability in P&L, allowed in income-tax assessment.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the statements furnished to the Controller of Insurance by the respondent for the relevant periods did disclose 40 per cent. of the premiums received as reserve for unexpired risks on the outstanding policies and that the same has been treated as a liability in its profits and loss statements and allowed in the assessment of income-tax.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds reserve for unexpired risks is not an accruing liability within r.2 Sch.II EPT Act.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot therefore be held to be an is accruing liability within r. 2 of Sch. 11 to the Act.

II.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; contingent liability does not affect real capital position or contribute to profits; noscitur a sociis limits to debt-like utilised assets.

arguments.claim: Reserve of 40% is sum in respect of accruing liability under r.2 as contract complete on policy issue, risk attaches, liability accruing while policy in force.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the learned Solicitor General is that it must be so regarded, and his argument in support of it may thus be stated A contract of insurance is complete as soon as the policy is issued. From that time, the risk begins to attach to it, and there is a liability incurred.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ling him to retain at least in part the profits realised by him by investment of additional capital. Then there is r. 2, which provides for certain de

arguments.court_reasoning: Accruing liability must be utilised in business like borrowed money/debts; insurance reserve is contingent, no real contribution to trading assets.

arguments.claim: Sun Insurance Office v. Clark supports deduction of reserves for unexpired risks as liability in computing profits.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this contention, the decision in Sun Insurance Office v. Clark was relied on. The facts of that case were as follows A fire insurance company which had been following the practice of entering in its annual statements 40 per cent. of the total premium receipts as reserve for unexpired risks claimed a deduction therefor in the assessment of its annual profits.

arguments.court_reasoning: Applicable to IT profits but not EPT capital; schemes differ, reserve unearned income not capital under EPT r1 anyway.

arguments.claim: Insurance contract is contingent under s.31 Indian Contract Act; no enforceable liability until event happens, so unexpired risks not present liability.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. K. P. Khaitan, learned counsel for the respondent, disputes the correctness of this contention. He argues that whatever the position under the English law, a contract of insurance is under the Indian Contract Act merely a contingent contract, that until the event specified in the policy happens, there is no enforceable liability,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed on. The facts of that case were as follows A fire insurance companypany which had been following the practice of entering in its annual statements

arguments.court_reasoning: Acknowledged but notes irrelevance for tax assessment; however aligns with contingent nature not affecting EPT capital.

arguments.claim: Accruing liabilities added to r.2 via amendment as part of debts/borrowed money, so must bear character of debts; insurance liability not debt until risk materialises.

anchor.surface_text: He also urges a further contention based on the history of the enactment of r. 2 of Sch. II to the Act. That rule as originally passed mentioned only borrowed money and debts, and it was by s. 10 of the Excess Profits Tax Amendment Act XLII of 1940 that accruing liabilities were brought within that rule.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees via noscitur a sociis; accruing liabilities same character as borrowed money/debts utilised in business.

arguments.claim: Webb v. Stenton and Israelson v. Dawson define debt/accruing debt as present obligation; insurance liability contingent until risk/claim ascertained, not debt.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this position, he relies on the decisions in Webb v. Stenton and Israelson Dawson Port of Manchester Insurance Co., Ltd., Garnishees. In Webb v. Stenton, the question was whether a sum which was payable to the judgment-debtor under a trust deed but which had not become due could be attached

arguments.claim: Reserve allowed as deduction in IT profits per r.6 Sch IT Act and practice under Insurance Act, satisfies one condition of r.2 EPT.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the statements furnished to the Controller of Insurance by the respondent for the relevant periods did disclose 40 per cent. of the premiums received as reserve for unexpired risks on the outstanding policies and that the same has been treated as a liability in its profits and loss statements and allowed in the assessment of income-tax.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: liability incurred. Rule 2 does number require that the liability should have actually accrued it is

arguments.court_reasoning: One condition satisfied, controversy on accruing liability.

arguments.claim: EPT Act differs from IT Act; principles for profits under IT s.10 not applicable to capital under EPT Sch.II rr1-2.

anchor.surface_text: But the fact is that the Excess Profits Tax Act differs, in material respects from the Income-tax Act, and the principles applicable in the assessment of profits under s. 10 of the latter enactment cannot necessarily be held to be applicable in the ascertainment of the capital employed under rr.1 and 2 of Sch. II to the former Act.

arguments.claim: Capital under r.1 Sch.II factual: all assets utilised in business; r.2 deducts borrowed money/debts to limit relief to assessee's own capital.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1 of Sch. II to the Act enumerates three categories of properties, which are to be included in the computation of capital. It is to be noted that this rule does not adopt any legalistic or conventional notion of what is technically termed capital but it proceeds on a factual basis to include whatever is utilised in business,

arguments.claim: Accruing liabilities under r.2 same character as borrowed money/debts per noscitur a sociis: must be utilised in business, part of effective trading assets contributing to profits.

anchor.surface_text: accruing liabilities which are liable to be deducted under r. 2 must also be of the same character as borrowed money and debts with which they are associated on the principle of noscitur a sociis. They must be such as can be said to have been utilised in the business and formed part of the really effective trading assets

arguments.claim: Reserve for unexpired risks not accruing liability under r.2: contingent, no factual contribution to business/profits, unlike debt/borrowed money.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot therefore be held to be an is accruing liability within r. 2 of Sch. 11 to the Act.

arguments.claim: Northern Aluminium supports: contingent liability under contract not accruing for EPT even if allowed in IT; no effect on real capital position.
Sun Insurance principle (unearned premium/liability analogy) inappropriate for EPT capital as premiums are capital under r.1, reserve not real trading asset.

holdings.text: Amounts shown by an insurance company as reserves for unexpired risks on pending policies are not liable to be deducted under r. 2 of Sch. II to the Excess Profits Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: 1957. April 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-This appeal raises a question of importance as to whether amounts shown by an insurance companypany as reserves for unexpired risks on pending policies are liable to be deducted under r. 2 of Sch. II to the Excess Profits Tax Act XV of 1940  hereinafter referred to as the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reserve for unexpired risks is a contingent liability that does not contribute to effective trading assets or real capital position unlike borrowed money or debts

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 40,000 set apart as reserve for unexpired risks is not liable to be deducted under r. 2 of Sch. II from capital employed including full premiums received

anchor.surface_text: Now, the question is whether in the illustration given above, the sum of Rs. 40,000 which is set apart in 1939 as reserve for unexpired risks is liable to be deducted under r. 2 of Sch. II to the Act from out of the capital employed in business for that year, which would, of companyrse, include the whole of Rs. 1,00,000 received as premiums.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reserve does not represent accruing liability of the character required under r. 2 as it is contingent and not utilised in business

holdings.text: Reserve of 40 per cent. cannot be regarded as a sum in respect of accruing liability under r. 2 Sch. II

anchor.surface_text: Thus, one of the companyditions required by r. 2 has been satisfied. The whole companytroversy between the parties relates to the other companydition whether the reserve of 40 per cent. can be regarded as a sum in respect of accruing liability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Although allowable in computing profits, it fails the second condition as not an accruing liability affecting capital employed

holdings.text: Provision for unexpired risks is a contingent liability not within r. 2 of Sch. II

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, while claiming that all the premiums received mu-,it be treated as capital, maintains that the provision for unexpired risks is- a companytingent liability, and that that 1005 is number within r. 2 of Sch. II.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contingent nature means no present obligation utilised in business; confirmed by contract law and noscitur a sociis

holdings.text: Unexpired risk in an outstanding policy is not an accruing liability within r. 2 of Sch. II to the Act

anchor.surface_text: But even so, on the footing that r. 6 in the Schedule to the Indian Income-tax Act has adopted the law as laid down in Sun Insurance Office v. Clark  1 , the question still, remains whether unexpired risk in an outstanding policy is an accruing liability within r. 2 of Sch. II to the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability contingent until risk materialises; does not form part of effective trading assets contributing to profits

holdings.text: Accruing liabilities deductible under r. 2 must be of the same character as borrowed money and debts on principle of noscitur a sociis; utilised in business and part of effective trading assets

anchor.surface_text: And 1015 accruing liabilities which are liable to be deducted under r. 2 must also be of the same character as borrowed money and debts with which they are associated on the principle of numbercitur a sociis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context of r. 2 limits to liabilities that swell capital under r. 1 like borrowings and debts to prevent abuse of relief

holdings.text: Principles applicable in assessment of profits under s. 10 Income-tax Act cannot necessarily be held applicable to ascertainment of capital employed under rr. 1 and 2 Sch. II Excess Profits Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: That would be so, if the scheme and framework of the Excess Profits Tax Act were the same as those of the Income. tax Act. But the fact is that the Excess Profits Tax Act differs, in material respects from the Income-tax Act, and the principles applicable in the assessment of profits under s. 10 of the latter enactment cannot necessarily be held to be applicable in the ascertainment of the capital employed under rr.1 and 2 of Sch. II to the former Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: EPT taxes excess over standard profits linked to capital employed on factual basis; IT focuses on net profits after deductions

holdings.text: Reserve for unexpired risks cannot be held to be an accruing liability within r. 2 of Sch. II to the Act

anchor.surface_text: It cannot therefore be held to be an is accruing liability within r. 2 of Sch. 11 to the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reserve liability could not factually contribute to running of business or earning of profits; something in the air with no effect on working

holdings.text: A contingent liability in respect of unexpired risk is not an accruing liability within r. 2 of Sch. II to the Act

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the principles laid down in Northern Aluminium Co., Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners  1  and Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Northern Aluminium Co., Ltd.  2   are applicable to the decision of the present case, and that a companytingent liability in respect of unexpired risk is number an accruing liability within r. 2 of Sch. II to the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Northern Aluminium: contingent liability does not affect company's capital position; allowable in IT but not EPT capital

anchor.surface_text: Sun Insurance Office v. Clark 1 was relied on. The facts of that case were as follows A fire insurance companypany which had been following the practice of entering in its annual statements 40 per cent. of the total premium receipts as reserve for unexpired risks claimed a deduction therefor in the assessment of its annual profits.

precedents.cited_proposition: Reserve for unexpired risks in fire insurance policies is deductible in computing profits for income tax purposes as it represents unearned premium or outstanding liability.
precedents.cited_holding: the amounts reserved for unexpired risks should be deducted [...] on the ground that the premium which had been paid in respect of a risk for a whole year could not be said to have been wholly earned [...] or as the premium had been received burdened with a liability which had been only partially discharged

precedents.citation: The General Accident Fire and Life Assurance Corporation v. McGowan 2

anchor.surface_text: The General Accident Fire and Life Assurance Corporation v. McGowan 2 . The case came on further appeal before the House of Lords which agreed with Bray J.that the deduction was admissible, and distinguished the decision in The General Accident Fire and Life Assurance Corporation v. McGowan 2

precedents.case_name: General Accident Fire and Life Assurance Corporation v McGowan
precedents.cited_proposition: Deduction for reserves on unexpired risks not allowable in income tax computation.

precedents.citation: Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles 1

anchor.surface_text: That case Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles 1 clearly decided that the receipts of a business are not in themselves profit and gains within the meaning of the Income Tax Acts

precedents.case_name: Gresham Life Assurance Society v Styles
precedents.cited_proposition: Receipts of a business are not in themselves profits and gains; what remains after deducting cost of earning them constitutes taxable profits.

precedents.citation: Scottish Union and National Insurance Company V. Smiles 2

anchor.surface_text: one of the authorities relied on for the Crown was the decision in Scottish Union and National Insurance Company V. Smiles 2 wherein, discussing how the reserve for unexpired risk in fire policies is to be dealt with in computing the profits

precedents.case_name: Scottish Union and National Insurance Company v Smiles
precedents.cited_proposition: Premiums received for fire insurance policies may be taken as profits without allowance for unexpired risks.
precedents.cited_holding: fire insurance policies are contracts for one year only, the premiums received for the year of assessment [...] may be fairly taken as profits and gains of the Company without [...] making any allowance for the balance of annual risks unexpired

anchor.surface_text: Webb v. Stenton 1 and Israelson Dawson Port of Manchester Insurance Co., Ltd., Garnishees 2 . In Webb v. Stenton 1 , the question was whether a sum which was payable to the judgment-debtor under a trust deed

precedents.cited_proposition: A debt is a sum of money presently payable or to become payable in future by reason of present obligation (debitum in praesenti, solvendum in futuro); accruing debt is existing obligation not yet payable.
precedents.cited_holding: a debt legal or equitable can be attached whether it be a debt owing or accruing but it must be debt, and a debt is a sum of money which is now payable or will become payable in the future by reason of a present obligation

precedents.citation: Israelson Dawson Port of Manchester Insurance Co., Ltd., Garnishees 2

anchor.surface_text: Israelson Dawson Port of Manchester Insurance Co., Ltd., Garnishees 2 . In Webb v. Stenton 1 , the question was whether a sum which was payable to the judgment-debtor under a trust deed but which had not become due could be attached

precedents.case_name: Israelson v Dawson (Port of Manchester Insurance Co Ltd Garnishees)
precedents.cited_proposition: Amount payable under insurance policy after accident but before compensation determined by arbitrator is not a debt attachable.

precedents.citation: Southern Railway of Peru Ltd. v. Owen 2

anchor.surface_text: Southern Railway of Peru Ltd. v. Owen 2 . There, the appellant Company operated a railway in Peru under a statutory scheme under which its employees were entitled to receive from it a lump sum payment on retirement

precedents.case_name: Southern Railway of Peru Ltd v Owen
precedents.cited_proposition: Accountancy valuation of contingent future liabilities (like pension payments) not deductible in income tax unless essential charge against year's receipts; distinguishes insurance unexpired risks.
precedents.cited_holding: there is a fundamental distinction between a contingent liability and a payment dependent on a contingency [...] the liability in Sun Insurance Office v. Clark was not, in my opinion, contingent but remained in force throughout the period of the insurance

precedents.citation: Northern Aluminium Co. Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners 1

anchor.surface_text: Northern Aluminium Co. Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners 1 . There, the question arose whether a conditional liability under a contract was an accruing liability within the corresponding provision in the English Excess Profits Tax Act.

precedents.case_name: Northern Aluminium Co Ltd v Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents.cited_proposition: Conditional liability which may or may not mature does not affect capital position and is not an accruing liability for excess profits tax purposes, even if deductible for income tax.
precedents.cited_holding: A purely conditional liability [...] is not one which falls within that language [...] it would be contrary to the whole conception underlying these capital provisions because a purely conditional liability [...] is not a thing which affects a companys capital position

precedents.citation: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Northern Aluminium Co. Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: Vide Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Northern Aluminium Co. Ltd. 1 . This decision establishes that a conditional liability under a concluded contract [...] was not an accruing liability for the purposes of the Excess Profits Tax Act

precedents.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v Northern Aluminium Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Affirms that conditional liability is not accruing liability deductible in excess profits tax capital computation.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the principles laid down in Northern Aluminium Co., Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners 1 and Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Northern Aluminium Co., Ltd. 2 are applicable to the decision of the present case, and that a c

anchor.surface_text: 1957. April 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-This appeal raises a question of importance as to whether amounts shown by an insurance companypany as reserves for unexpired risks on pending policies are liable to be deducted under r. 2 of Sch. II to the Excess Profits Tax Act XV of 1940  hereinafter referred to as the Act.

We are of opinion that the principles laid down in Northern Aluminium Co., Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners 1 and Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Northern Aluminium Co., Ltd. 2 are applicable to the decision of the present case, and that a c

edges.explanation: Holding directly answers the issue by concluding the principles cannot necessarily be applied to capital ascertainment.

anchor.surface_text: That would be so, if the scheme and framework of the Excess Profits Tax Act were the same as those of the Income. tax Act. But the fact is that the Excess Profits Tax Act differs, in material respects from the Income-tax Act, and the principles applicable in the assessment of profits under s. 10 of the latter enactment cannot necessarily be held to be applicable in the ascertainment of the capital employed under rr.1 and 2 of Sch. II to the former Act.
